newsitem.title: UK: Britain's religious leaders call for moral society.
newsitem.headline: Britain's religious leaders call for moral society.

text.p: Religious leaders in Britain have joined together and supported a campaign for a more caring and moral society launched by the widow of a headmaster knifed to death outside his school.

France Lawrence outlined her "manifesto for the nation" -- a call for a nationwide movement to banish violence, encourage children to learn civic values and promote the family -- in a full-page article in The Times newspaper on Monday.
The leaders of Britain's Anglicans, Roman Catholics and Jews said the time was right to do something to make Britain a less violent society.

"I think people are deeply concerned about violence in our society. Broadly I think people want something to happen. I believe we can seize a particular tide and do something about it," Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey, leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans, told BBC television.

He referred to the killing of 16 schoolchildren by a lone gunman in Dunblane, Scotland in March and the murder of Philip Lawrence, 48, who was stabbed in December as he tried to stop a gang attack on a pupil at his London school.
Carey called for more stable family lives supported by parenting classes and more emphasis on the teaching of right and wrong in schools.
Prime Minister John Major and opposition politicians, aware that it will be an issue in the general election due by next May, have already endorsed Lawrence's plea.
But Tuesday was the first time Britain's main religious leaders spoke out.
Dr Jonathan Sacks, Britain's chief rabbi, called for the establishment of a royal commission on the question of teaching citizenship.
Cardinal Basil Hume, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Britain which issued its own document on Monday on the need for a fair society, emphasised the need to act now.
